fields.headline: Race to protect Spanish shoreline
fields.bodyText: Welcome to the Informer, Guardian Unlimited's 2pm news round-up. THE NEWS IN 90 SECONDS RACE TO PROTECT SHORELINES FROM OIL An armada of clean-up and salvage vessels was hampered by strong winds and rough seas today as it attempted to control the surface oil slick in the area where the tanker Prestige went down. The home secretary, David Blunkett, today dismissed as "dangerous" Tory calls for the appointment of a new Cabinet minister for homeland security to deal with the threat of terrorism. Police arrested three people on suspicion of murder last night after parts of a boy's dismembered body were found dumped in a canal and scattered around nearby streets. The Bank of England's monetary policy committee voted 7-2 to hold interest rates steady earlier this month amid concern that a rate cut would feed the housing market frenzy, it emerged today. The government published the final draft of its much-heralded new communications bill today, complete with a few surprises. Most Americans believe the UK is a country "somewhere" in the Middle East, according to the tourism minister, Kim Howells. House prices are continuing to power ahead and look set to remain strong until the end of the year, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors. MARKETS UPDATE The FTSE 100 was down 16.6 points or 0.4% at 4,079.9 on lower oil shares as Middle East tensions eased, but Lloyds TSB rose as fears of a dividend cut receded following analysts' comments. EDITOR'S PICK The latest Bond movie, Die Another Day, opens today. Read the Guardian's original review of one of the first - Goldfinger. IN THE GUARDIAN TOMORROW * In Online: Jack Schofield's tips on how to buy a good quality digital camera for Christmas * Rhianna Pratchett joins the gamers thrashing it out at Britain's biggest local area network gaming party * In Science: Mowing lawns and blasting weeds with a laser ITALY DISPATCH The conviction of Giulio Andreotti for a journalist's murder has confirmed what many always thought about the former prime minister, says Philip Willan. TODAY'S CROSSWORD CLUE Wait with viscosity (5) Find the rest of today's cryptic crossword, and the ability to cheat, here. AND FINALLY "The Kiribati sense of humour does not encompass satire," the New Zealand high commissioner to the tiny Pacific state told the Associated Press. He was explaining why a spoof article that appeared on a NZ website, Spinner.co.nz - and claimed the United States was about to invade the island - was taken literally by the islanders. Kiribati, which was formerly a British colony known as the Gilbert Islands, consists of a chain of 33 coral atolls and has a population of less than 100,000, the Sydney Morning Herald reports. Its president, Teburoro Tito, was forced to issue a series of broadcasts repudiating the story. Sydney Morning Herald * Thanks to Ben Shepherd for nominating this story.
